content.statement: vascular:venous:svd-001a-gsv-anatomy is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Venous that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding vascular:venous:svd-001a-gsv-anatomy helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of vascular:venous:svd-001a-gsv-anatomy include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of vascular:venous:svd-001a-gsv-anatomy.

definitions_glossary.concept: A fundamental idea or notion in the domain
definitions_glossary.property: A characteristic or attribute of an entity
definitions_glossary.relationship: A connection or association between concepts

anatomic_course.origin: Medial marginal vein of dorsal foot, anterior to medial malleolus
anatomic_course.lower_leg: Ascends medial calf in saphenous compartment
anatomic_course.knee_region: Crosses from posterior to anterior around medial tibial condyle
anatomic_course.thigh: Lies posteromedially, curves anteriorly approaching SFJ

saphenous_compartment.ultrasound_appearance: Saphenous eye - hyperechoic fascia above and below creates eye shape
saphenous_compartment.clinical_significance: Protects GSV from external compression; confirms GSV identity

saphenous_nerve.injury_risk: Stripping or thermal ablation below knee

neural_relationships.prevention: Limit treatment to above-knee segment when possible

presentation: Visible medial leg and thigh varicosities
Heaviness, aching, fatigue in affected leg
Symptoms worse with standing, better with elevation
Skin changes in gaiter area with advanced disease
diagnosis: Assess reflux with Valsalva (SFJ) and compression maneuvers
Map tributaries, perforators, and accessory veins
treatment: Preserve GSV if suitable bypass conduit needed

definition.@value: The anatomy and course of the great saphenous vein from its origin at the medial foot to its termination at the saphenofemoral junction, including its relationship to the saphenous compartment and neural structures.

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Trace GSV course from foot to SFJ
Describe the saphenous compartment and 'saphenous eye'
Identify neural relationships for injury prevention
Apply GSV anatomy to procedure planning
clinical_pearls: The 'saphenous eye' on ultrasound confirms you're looking at the true GSV, not a tributary
Saphenous nerve runs with GSV below knee - limit stripping/ablation to above-knee when possible
The GSV is the most commonly harvested bypass conduit - always assess before ablation
Accessory saphenous veins are common and can be independent sources of reflux/recurrence
The GSV curves anteriorly at the SFJ - follow the vein, don't assume location

medicalCode.description: Asymptomatic varicose veins of unspecified lower extremity
